text: the islamic center at NYU is basically
an institution within the division of
student affairs at New York University
we serve about a student population of
2,000 of young Muslims coming from all
walks of life their diverse ethnically
in terms of religiosity you know the
representative of various sects of Islam
they share a commonality in that they're
trying to figure out what their identity
means in terms of an American context so
the premise of this group meeting and
having a discussion was to kind of go
through the ideas of a presence or
prevalence of Islamophobia in the recent
presidential elections I mean I find it
offensive because we are Americans as
well I mean we contribute to society we
pay taxes we go to school here I was
born here I was raised here um so I'm
just like everyone else and to be
associated because I'm a Muslim to be
associated with terrorism or terrorist
it's it's it's ignorant because most
people don't understand that there's
over a billion Muslims worldwide and the
entire Muslim population is not
terrorists that there are a few fanatics
out there yes but that doesn't that
shouldn't define who we are what we are
as a as a society as a group we all know
that Colin Powell had made some
statements on Meet the Press you know he
was one of the first people if not the
first one to actually Blissett Lee asked
the question even if Obama was Muslim
what would be the problem throughout the
whole thing I felt like a liability it
wasn't I couldn't participate in the
campaign because I thought you know
maybe someone will look at it and say
well she's Muslim and she's campaigning
for Barack Obama meaning brock obama is
muslim in fact I didn't even put a
Barack Obama sticker on my bag or on my
jacket or anything until Colin Powell
said you know well so what just because
um and I shouldn't have to feel that way
and it was it was so hurtful I mean I
shouldn't have to hide my feelings if I
want a campaign if I wanna phone back I
shouldn't have to think well well they
want to hide me in the corner what they
want me to sit in
back so that that hurt a lot we even had
you know the instance where you actually
were you know girls who were wearing
headscarves wearing hijabs you know
found behind obama you know on one
occasion and you know they were asked to
get moved out of the shot and again you
know the question comes about you know
how is that something that's okay and
where were we or where were our own
voices you know and speaking out about
this as well when I found out that they
moved those girls wearing scarves behind
obama you know what people can say sold
out but I was like you know what I would
have moved them too I just over the last
eight years the Muslim identity has been
vilified and as much as a few people are
like you know I'm just like everyone
else I haven't felt like everybody else
I was born here as born in Queens
haven't felt like everybody else I felt
vilified I was not an American Muslims
Muslim American I was proud of my
religion i also just assumed America
would never understand I will always be
the villain so Obama going out there and
just trying to kind of stay away from it
to me just made a lot of sense it's been
a it's been up on uphill climb these
past eight years with 911 and the Bush
presidency um but you know unless we
speak up and actually do something
ourselves to make ourselves feel more
like we are American and we want to be
recognized in that same way I don't
think we're going to have that same type
of response from political figures in
2012 let's say if you know another more
progressive individual you know it comes
into play and we don't voice our opinion
will we be well represented so that's
the question for us to ask ourselves
